a.HREF: mailto:?subject=From the St. Stephen%27s Episcopal School website&body=I saw this on the St. Stephen%27s Episcopal School website and thought it may interest you: http%3a%2f%2fwww.sstx.org%2fgiving

tr.td:
THE RT. REV. JOHN E. HINES — AN ENDURING VISION
A FAR-REACHING MISSION
When Bishop John Hines founded St. Stephen's Episcopal School in 1950, he envisioned a school with the highest academic standards that would welcome people from around the world and across the socioeconomic spectrum. Hines, who became Presiding Bishop of the U.S. Episcopal Church from 1964 to 1974, dedicated his life to teaching and encouraging people from diverse backgrounds to find equitable, just, and peaceful solutions to divisive problems. St. Stephen's embodies Bishop Hines' lifelong goal. Indeed, his legacy is a mission as noble and relevant today as it was at the school's founding.
St. Stephen's Episcopal School, a coeducational boarding and day school of the Diocese of Texas, is a caring, diverse community, inclusive of all faiths and grounded in the Christian tradition, that nurtures moral growth and values the potential and dignity of every human being. We challenge motivated students to live intelligently, creatively, and humanely as contributing members of society. We develop the whole person by providing rigorous academic preparation, stimulating physical activities, and rich opportunities in the fine arts.
A TRADITION OF PHILANTHROPY
Significant financial support from parents, grandparents, trustees, alumni, faculty, staff, friends, foundations, and businesses has been essential in making Bishop Hines' vision for St. Stephen's a reality. Annual contributions for operations bridge the gap between what tuition covers and the actual cost of running the school. Gifts for capital improvements and other special projects have enabled the creation of exceptional programs and facilities such as the Helm Fine Arts Center, Katherine Sage Temple Dormitory, Clayton Gymnasium, and St. Stephen's Observatory. Most recently, the successful Hill Project campaign allowed the school to renovate and add the new Linda Lanham Douglass Middle School Addition and construct the Arthur Temple, Jr. Upper School Academic Center. With these new spaces, we are accommodating the existing student population in appropriate learning facilities and enhancing the excellent academic environment. It is critical that we build upon our proud tradition of philanthropy to make certain that St. Stephen's has the resources to sustain excellent teaching and learning for present and future generations, to continue to be accessible to a broad socioeconomic range of students, and to prepare our students to both live intelligently and creatively and find opportunities to serve others in the midst of the global challenges of the 21st century. Increasing the school's endowment is an immediate priority to meet these goals and to ensure that St. Stephen's cherished mission and core values are carried forward as the living center of school life.
